title: Font from an old VU meter
content:
The image is from the Wikipedia article "VU Meter" - I feel that this style of font, with the very low cross on the A and the distinctive K, is often seen on older technical equipment like this but I can't seem to identify anything exactly like it. If anyone has any ideas that would be great!

[http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VU\_meter](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VU_meter)

Thanks.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246im_/http:/typophile.com/files/peak_5646.png)

EDIT: Thanks a lot guys; I think idiotcountry got the closest here, cheers!

Font: 

 Akzidenz-Grotesk Extended 

Solved By: 

 [idiotcountry](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/typophile.com/user/38820 "View user profile.")

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [peak.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/typophile.com/files/peak.png) | 1.89 KB |
author: jbr

comments.content: I guess [Engravers Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/engravers+gothic/)/ [Blair](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/blair/)/ [Sackers Gothic](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/sackers+gothic/) could do the job.

Trade Gothic Extended  
 [http://www.linotype.com/47718/tradegothicextended-font.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/www.linotype.com/47718/tradegothicextended-font.html "http://www.linotype.com/47718/tradegothicextended-font.html")

or most likely

Akzidenz-Grotesk Extended  
 [http://www.linotype.com/257461/akzidenzgroteskbqextended-font.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20140831034246/http:/www.linotype.com/257461/akzidenzgroteskbqextended-font.html "http://www.linotype.com/257461/akzidenzgroteskbqextended-font.html")
